children.name: famous
children.definition: famous people, places, books etc are known about and talked about by a lot of people in a lot of places: nổi tiếng
examples: a famous actor
Many famous people have stayed in the hotel.
The Eiffel Tower is afamous landmark(= a famous place or building that is easy to recognize ).
famous for
France is famous for its wine.
famous as
Virginia is famous as the birthplace of several US presidents.
world-famousfamous all over the world nổi tiếng thế giới
Rio’s world-famous carnival
Da Vinci’sworld-famousportrait of the Mona Lisa
a nightclub used bythe rich and famous
The night club is popular among the rich and famous.

children.name: the famous[
examples: P] people who are famous :

children.name: the rich and famous[
examples: P] people who are rich and famous:

children.name: well known
children.definition: well-known/ known about by a lot of people, especially in a particular place: được biết đến
examples: She works in local radio, and is quite well known in the Houston area.
Large companies have an advantage because of their well-known brand names.
it is well-known (that)
It’s a well-known fact that smoking can cause lung cancer.
This is probably their best-known song.
a well-known TV presenter
well-known for
He was well-known for his extreme political views.
better-known/best-knownđược biết đến rộng rãi
▪ Pat Boone is one of America’s best-known Christian entertainers.

children.name: legendary
children.definition: very famous and greatly admired – used especially about people who have been doing sth for a long time or who have died: lừng danh, thần kỳ, “truyền thuyết”
examples: The studio was owned by Sam Goldwyn, the legendary Hollywood producer.
The album was recorded at the legendary Abbey Road studios.

children.name: the legendary blues guitarist, BB King
examples: Her stage performances were legendary.

children.name: celebrated
children.definition: very well known, admired, and talked about by a lot of people, especially because of some special success or achievement: lừng danh
examples: ▪ Martin Luther King Jr. gave his celebrated speech before the Lincoln Memorial in 1963.
▪ Van Gogh, perhaps Holland’s most celebrated artist, died in poverty.

children.name: noted
children.definition: noted musician/scientist/surgeon etcwell known and respected because of a special ability or achievement.Notedis more formal thanrenowned: nổi tiếng, danh tiếng
examples: The picture was taken in the mid-1880s by the noted photographer C.S. Fly.
The author quotes Stephen Jay Gould, the noted Harvard scientist, to support his theories.

children.name: renowned
children.definition: known and admired by a lot of people, especially for a special skill, achievement, or quality: trứ danh
examples: Jesse Jackson, the renowned civil rights leader, was in the city again last night.
Aninternationally renownedchef owns the restaurant.
renowned author/actor/photographer etc
a world renowned expert in the field
renowned for
an island renowned for its beauty
renowned as
He’s renowned as a brilliant speaker.

children.name: eminent
children.definition: an eminent doctor, lawyer, scientist etcis famous for being extremely successful in his or her profession and is admired and respected for this: kiệt xuất, lỗi lạc, xuất chúng
examples: She’s an eminent psychiatrist at the Harvard Medical School.
While he lived, Nehru remained the most eminent spokesman for the Third World.

children.name: become famous
children.definition: /well known  nổi tiếng
examples: ▪ Many people dream of becoming famous.
▪ The brand name has become well known in Britain through clever advertising.

children.name: become famous overnightvery suddenly : nổi tiếng trong một sớm một chiều
examples: ▪ With the success of their first record, they became famous overnight.

children.name: become well known
children.definition: become famous/well known  nổi tiếng
examples: ▪ Many people dream of becoming famous.
▪ The brand name has become well known in Britain through clever advertising.

children.name: become famous overnightvery suddenly : nổi tiếng trong một sớm một chiều
examples: ▪ With the success of their first record, they became famous overnight.

children.name: make your name
children.definition: /make a name for yourself  to become well known, especially as a result of hard work or an unusual achievement:

children.name: tạo lên tên tuổi
examples: ▪ Clint Eastwood first made a name for himself in the TV series ‘Rawhide’.

children.name: make your name/make a name for yourself as tạo nên tên tuổi như là
examples: ▪ By the time he was 30, Evans had made his name as the editor of ‘The Sunday Times’.
▪ She is beginning to make a name for herself as a fashion designer.

children.name: rise to fame
children.definition: /shoot to fame/win fame (as) to become famous, especially suddenly: ngôi sao mới nổi
examples: ▪ John Lydon shot to fame in the mid-1970s as Johnny Rotten of the Sex Pistols.
▪ She won fame as the youngest-ever Olympic champion gymnast.

children.name: achieve notoriety
children.definition: to become famous for sth bad: đạt được tai tiếng
examples: ▪ The director’s films have achieved notoriety for their graphic depiction of violence.

children.name: achieve a certain notorietybecome slightly famous for something đạt được tai tiếng
examples: ▪ The club has achieved a certain notoriety as a meeting place for criminals and drug dealers.

children.name: hit the headlines
children.definition: /make (the) headlines  to suddenly become very famous and receive a lot of attention from the newspapers, television etc, sometimes only for a short time: trang đầu
examples: ▪ The island hit the headlines last year when huge tidal waves killed 2,000 people.
▪ The bizarre court case was shown on TV and made headlines around the world.

children.name: rising star
children.definition: someone, especially a young person, who is quickly becoming more and more famous: ngôi sao đang lên
examples: ▪ She’s one of the rising stars of politics and an excellent public speaker.

children.name: all-star
children.definition: including many famous actors, sports players etc: toàn sao

children.name: an all-star baseball team
examples: The video performance with all-star backup singers was a bit odd.
Since then we've done all-star performances in London with sixty-five colleges.

children.name: an all-star cast
examples: His latest film featured an all-starcast.
It's a contemporary version with an a less than all-star cast.

children.name: star
children.definition: a very famous and successful actor, entertainer, or sports player: ngôi sao
examples: Hollings’ latest movie role could make her a big star.

children.name: a big star
children.definition: a very famous and successful star
examples: He has worked with some of the world’s biggest stars.

children.name: a movie/Hollywood star
children.definition: alsoa film starespecially British English
examples: He looked like a movie star.

children.name: a pop/rock star
examples: Who’s your favourite pop star?

children.name: a
examples: TV starMost TV stars do quite a lot of charity work.

children.name: a soap star
children.definition: a star in a television soap opera
examples: She was known as a soap star before she took up singing.

children.name: a sports/football/basketball etc star
examples: Sam was a football star in college.

children.name: an international star
children.definition: a star who is famous in many countries
examples: His performance in 'The Titanic' made him an international star.

children.name: a rising star
children.definition: someone who is becoming famous and successful
examples: She is very much the rising star of Black American fiction.

children.name: a child star
children.definition: a child who is a famous performer
examples: The production team say they have been careful to look after all their child stars.

children.name: star quality
children.definition: a special quality that could make someone a star
examples: She radiates genuine star quality.

children.name: star treatment
children.definition: special treatment that a star gets
examples: Winners get star treatment from the media.

children.name: a star vehicle
children.definition: a film or television programme that is intended to show the abilities of one particular star
examples: He denied that the movie was just a star vehicle for Tom Hanks.

children.name: a star of stage and screen
children.definition: a star who has been in plays and films
examples: Now this much-loved star of stage and screen has been made a Dame.

children.name: name
children.definition: a famous person whose name is known by many people – used especially in the following expressions:
examples: Giorgio Armani is one of the mostfamous namesin fashion.
big nameinformal a famous and successful performer: tên tuổi lớn
All the big names in football were at the awards dinner.
Eric Hawkins, one of the big names of modern American dance
household namea person, company, or product that is a household name is so famous that everyone knows their name: cái tên thân thuộc
He is yet to become a household name(= someone who everyone has heard of ).
Coca-Cola is a household name all over the world.
make sb/sth a household name
Ralph Nader’s consumer activism has made him a household name in the U.S.
big-name[adj] tên tuổi lớn
The stadium has managed to attract a number of big-name entertainers.

children.name: celebrity
children.definition: /celebinformal  sb who is well known, for example as an entertainer or sports player, and who is often seen on television or written about in newspapers.Celebritiesare often famous for being famous, not because they have any great talent: người nổi tiếng
examples: People waited outside for the chance to see some celebrities.
The bar is a good place to go if you want to spot some celebs.

children.name: TV/showbusiness/media etc celebrity
examples: The club is popular with media celebrities and literary types.

children.name: celebrity interview/photograph/biography etc
examples: Mattie reads mainly tabloids and celebrity biographies.

children.name: celebrity golf tournament/game showin which celebrities take part giải golf, chương trình trò chơi cùng các nghệ sĩ
examples: Nash played in a celebrity golf tournament while in Canada.

children.name: minor celebritynot extremely famous, popular, or successful
examples: Six minor celebrities took part in the charity ‘Big Brother’ programme.

children.name: personality
children.definition: someone who is very famous and often appears in the newspapers, on television etc, especially an entertainer or sports person: người nổi tiếng
examples: For years she was one of the best-loved personalities in the newspaper gossip columns.

children.name: TV/radio/sports etc personality nhân vật TV, radio, thể thao
examples: Radio personality Don Imus has gotten in trouble again for what he said on the air.

children.name: one of the most well-liked TV personalities
fame
children.definition: the state of being known about by a lot of people because of your achievements: tiếng tăm, danh vọng
examples: He claims he is not really interested in fame.
of television/movie/baseball etc fame(= used to show what someone is famous for )
The book is about Bonnie Parker of Bonnie and Clyde fame.
Muhammad Ali, of boxing fame
at the height of sb’s famewhen sb is most famous : ở đỉnh cao của danh vọng
At the height of his fame, it is estimated that 500 million people watched his show.

children.name: win/gain fame
examples: He won fame when he appeared in the film ‘The Graduate’.

children.name: achieve/find fame
examples: Amy Johnson found fame as a pilot.

children.name: bring/win somebody/something fame
examples: Chomsky’s theories about language brought him fame.

children.name: rise to fame
children.definition: become famous
examples: She rose to fame during the early Sixties.

children.name: shoot to fame
children.definition: become famous very suddenly
examples: She shot to fame as a result of her victory in the Olympics.

children.name: seek fame
children.definition: try to become famous
examples: He sought fame in the jazz clubs of New York.

children.name: enjoy fame
children.definition: be famous
examples: The town briefly enjoyed fame as the location of a popular television series.

children.name: international/worldwide fame
examples: Edinburgh achieved international fame as a centre of medical education.

children.name: national fame
examples: Her oil paintings won her national fame.

children.name: lasting fame
children.definition: being famous for a long time
examples: Diderot gained lasting fame as the editor of the French Encyclopaedia.

children.name: brief fame
children.definition: being famous for a short time
examples: Ed achieved brief fame as a pop singer in the late 1980s.

children.name: instant fame
examples: The success of her first novel brought her instant fame.

children.name: great fame
examples: His acting ability brought him great fame.

children.name: new-found fame
examples: Anna was finding it difficult to get used to her new-found fame.

children.name: sb’s/sth’s rise to fame
examples: Her rise to fame has been astonishingly rapid.

children.name: at the height of sb’s/sth’s fame
children.definition: when someone was most famous
examples: At the height of his fame, he could earn $5,000 a day.

children.name: sb’s/sth’s claim to fame
children.definition: reason for being famous
examples: One of his main claims to fame is having invented the electric light bulb.

children.name: fame and fortune
children.definition: being rich and famous
examples: He came to London to seek fame and fortune.

children.name: stardom
children.definition: when sb is very famous, especially in music, films, or sport: địa vị ngôi sao
examples: Stardom is the ultimate ambition of most young singers and actors.
She feared that by having a baby she had sacrificed her chances of stardom.
his rapid rise to stardom
shoot/rise/zoom to stardom(= become famous very quickly )
Ellen shot to stardom as a model last year.

children.name: renown
children.definition: fame and admiration that sb has because of sth good such as great skill, knowledge, or bravery: danh tiếng
examples: The general’s victories won him renown throughout the country.

children.name: international/public etc renown
examples: He haswonworldrenownfor his films.
Heachievedsomerenownas a football player.

children.name: of great/international/high etc renown
examples: Speakers of international renown will attend the conference.

children.name: unknown
children.definition: not at all famous: không được biết đến, vô danh
examples: ▪ As an unknown author, it isn’t easy to get your work published.
▪ Horn was beaten by a relatively unknown politician in the last election.
unknown[C] vô danh
▪ a movie made with a cast of complete unknowns

children.name: a nobody
children.definition: sb who is very ordinary and not at all famous or important: người tầm thường
examples: ▪ After all her hard work, she didn’t want to end up just a nobody.
▪ A lot of the rich people who come in here treat us like nobodies.

children.name: obscure
children.definition: sb/sth that is obscure is known about only by a few people, because they belong to a group, place, or subject that not many people know about or are interested in: không tiếng tăm
examples: ▪ He’s using an obscure old law to try to stop the new road being built.
▪ The lines were written by an obscure English poet named Mordaunt.

children.name: receiving a lot of attention in newspapers etc
be in the public eye
children.definition: to receive a lot of attention, so that a lot of what you do is reported in newspapers, on television etc: ở giữa sự chú ý
examples: ▪ The President’s family is constantly in the public eye.
▪ Marks has kept himself in the public eye for years by filing bizarre lawsuits.

children.name: be in the spotlight
children.definition: /limelight  to receive a lot of attention in newspapers, on television etc, but often only for a short period of time: trung tâm dư luận
examples: ▪ The band is in the spotlight again because of its recent hit single.
▪ How do her children feel about having a mother who’s constantly in the limelight?

children.name: most talked about U
children.definition: much/most talked about  receiving a lot of attention from newspapers, television etc, and talked about by a lot of people: thường được nhắc đến
examples: ▪ The much talked about new museum is somewhat disappointing.
▪ She is Australia’s most talked about TV actress.

children.name: sb’s name is on everyone’s lips
children.definition: somebody’s name is on everyone’s lips if someone’s name is on everyone’s lips they are very well known and talked about for a short time, usually as a result of a news story: được nhắc đến dạo này
examples: ▪ As a result of the scandal, the tall Texan millionaire’s name was on everyone’s lips.

children.name: high-profile
children.definition: often attracting a lot of attention because of your position in society or your job: nổi danh
examples: ▪ a high-profile civil rights lawyer
▪ a high-profile position as Chief Executive

children.name: notorious
children.definition: famous because of doing something bad: khét tiếng
examples: One of Britain’s most notorious criminals has escaped from prison.
Davis is a notorious woman-hater.
a notorious criminal
a notorious legal case
notorious for
English soccer fans are notorious for their drunkenness.

children.name: infamous
children.definition: famous for being bad, especially for being immoral or evil: khét tiếng
examples: He was a member of the regime’s infamous secret police.
The night club is named after New Orleans’ infamous red light district.
an infamous killer
Los Angeles’ infamous smog
infamous for
This area is infamous for drugs and prostitution.

children.name: superstar
children.definition: an actor, musician, or sports player who is extremely famous all over the world:
examples: The film made Tom Cruise an international superstar.
Janet Jackson became a superstar largely because of her exciting music videos.

children.name: radio/TV/basketball etc superstar ngôi sao radio, TV, bóng rổ thế giới
examples: Hockey superstar Wayne Gretzky played for L.A. before retiring.

children.name: legend
children.definition: sb who is famous and admired for being extremely good at doing sth – used especially about people who are at the end of a long career or who have died: huyền thoại
examples: Among Mexican music fans, Fernandez is a legend.
a marvellous player who wasa legend inhisown lifetime
living legendin somebody’s own lifetime someone who has become a legend while still alive huyền thoại sống
Michael Jordan is a living legend of basketball.
tennis/footballing/music etc legend
We must put more money into the sport if we want to create the tennis legends of the future.

children.name: great
children.definition: sb who was one of the best players or performers that there have ever been: vĩ đại
examples: He was one of the all-time soccer greats.
Jack Nicklaus is one of golf’sall-time greats.
I think his show’s OK, but I wouldn’t call him one of the greats.

children.name: icon
children.definition: sb famous who is admired by many people and is thought to represent an important idea: thần tượng

children.name: a sixties cultural icon
examples: Marilyn Monroe and James Dean are still icons for many young people.
